abstract: Robert M. Godsell, the chief executive of AngloGold Ashanti, plans to retire after running the company since its creation in 1998 and helping it become the world’s third-biggest gold producer with operations in 10 countries. Mr. Godsell, left, who will step down on September 30, will be succeeded by Mark Cutifani, the chief operating officer of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce’s nickel unit, AngloGold said. Mr. Godsell, 54, was the chief executive of Anglo American’s gold and uranium division from 1995 before taking over as head of AngloGold, a company formed by a merger of Anglo American’s separately traded gold companies and the gold assets of Minorco. Other acquisitions included Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana.

abstract: Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru cars, posted a loss for the first time in eight quarters after sales declined in the United States and Japan. The net loss was 332 million yen ($2.8 million), or 0.46 yen a share, compared with a profit of 4.6 billion yen, or 6.42 yen, a year earlier, Fuji said. Sales fell 3.4 percent, to 318.2 billion yen from 329.5 billion yen. Separately, Suzuki Motor said first-quarter profit rose 20 percent, helped by increased sales of compact cars in Asia and Europe and a weaker yen. Net income climbed to 24.4 billion yen ($205.3 million), compared with 20.3 billion yen, a year earlier, the Tokyo-based company said. Sales rose 17 percent, to 894.5 billion yen. Mazda said first-quarter profit fell 63 percent as losses from currency hedging more than doubled. Net income fell to 2.48 billion yen ($21 million), from 6.61 billion yen, a year earlier. Sales rose 11 percent, to 814.3 billion yen. Mazda is based in Hiroshima.

lead_paragraph: TIP OF THE WEEK: Software like Adobe Photoshop and Microsoft’s Office suite are industry standards — and expensive. If you’re on a budget and not afraid of working without telephone support, consider open-source software. Developed by programmers all pitching in — and available to download free — open-source programs let you create files in standard formats at a price that is hard to beat. For image editing, there’s the GIMP at http://gimp.org/. The software suite at OpenOffice.org offers a word processor, a spreadsheet program and more. Both have versions available for Windows, Linux and Mac OS X.

lead_paragraph: Arcelor Mittal, the world’s biggest steel maker, reported a 50 percent increase in second-quarter profit, more than analysts had estimated, after raising prices in Europe and the Americas and accelerating cost savings. Net income climbed to $2.72 billion, or $1.97 a share, the Luxembourg-based company said. That compares with $1.82 billion, or $1.31 a share, based on figures Arcelor Mittal calculated as if it had existed a year earlier. Sales gained 21 percent, to $27.2 billion. Arcelor Mittal said it was ahead of schedule in reaping the cost benefits of its $38.3 billion combination last year.

lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard introduced the first hand-held scientific calculator in 1972 and sent the engineer’s stalwart slide rule the way of the buggy whip. Named the HP-35 because it had 35 keys, the pocket-size device sold 10 times as well as expected in its first year, no small feat considering that it cost $400. abstract: Japanese land prices rose 8.6 percent last year, more than nine times faster than in 2005, when a 16-year property slump ended as the country’s economy rebounded.
snippet: Japanese land prices rose 8.6 percent last year, more than nine times faster than in 2005, when a 16-year property slump ended as the country’s economy rebounded.
lead_paragraph: Japanese land prices rose 8.6 percent last year, more than nine times faster than in 2005, when a 16-year property slump ended as the country’s economy rebounded. The average land price jumped to 126,000 yen ($1,063) a square meter, the National Tax Agency said. In 2005, land prices rose 0.9 percent. Prices in Tokyo, home to a 10th of Japan’s population, increased for a third year, surging 17 percent to 570,000 yen a square meter in 2006. Land prices are recovering after dropping by more than half from their peak in 1991. Prices rose or were stable for the first time in 15 years in areas outside the three largest regions  Tokyo, Osaka and Nagoya. The most expensive land nationwide was again in the fifth block of Ginza, a central shopping district in Tokyo, where prices soared by a third, to 24.9 million yen a square meter. That is still about a third less than peak prices in 1991.

headline.main: Japan: Land Values Rise
headline.print_headline: Japan: Land Values Rise

abstract: South Korea’s exports grew at the fastest rate in six months in July, as global demand was strong enough to counter the effects of a stronger won.
snippet: South Korea’s exports grew at the fastest rate in six months in July, as global demand was strong enough to counter the effects of a stronger won.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s exports grew at the fastest rate in six months in July, as global demand was strong enough to counter the effects of a stronger won. Exports rose 20 percent from a year ago after climbing 15.3 percent in June, the commerce ministry said. Exports climbed to $30.9 billion and imports gained 14.9 percent to $29.4 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $1.6 billion in July, the ministry said. Mobile-phone exports gained 30.5 percent in the first 20 days of July from the same period last year, the ministry said. Shipments to China, South Korea’s largest trading partner, rose an estimated 30.4 percent in the first 20 days of July from a year ago. Exports to the United States gained 24.7 percent, the report showed.

headline.main: South Korea: Exports Surge

abstract: Assicurazioni Generali, Italy’s largest insurer, reported first-half profit that beat analysts’ estimates and agreed to sell its Nuova Tirrena unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.71 billion).
snippet: Assicurazioni Generali, Italy’s largest insurer, reported first-half profit that beat analysts’ estimates and agreed to sell its Nuova Tirrena unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.71 billion).
lead_paragraph: Assicurazioni Generali, Italy’s largest insurer, reported first-half profit that beat analysts’ estimates and agreed to sell its Nuova Tirrena unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.71 billion). Net income advanced to 1.78 billion euros from 1.4 billion euros a year earlier, the company said. Generali’s first-half operating result from its Italian life insurance business rose 14 percent, to 979 million euros, as the company made a greater proportion of its premiums from its proprietary sales network. Gross domestic life insurance premiums fell 10 percent, to 8.35 billion euros, as bank sales dropped 34 percent. Generali, based in Trieste, Italy, is considering acquisitions abroad as the Italian life insurance market contracts, and it will use funds from the sale of Nuova Tirrena, a car insurer, to expand internationally.

headline.main: EUROPE | Italy: Insurer’s Income Tops Estimates

lead_paragraph: South Korea halted imports of beef from the United States after a shipment from Cargill was found to contain a bone part banned as a precaution against mad cow disease. South Korea’s quarantine authority found a piece of the vertebral column of a cow in one of 1,176 boxes from a shipment imported on July 29 weighing 18.7 metric tons, the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry said. Cargill said it had packaged the beef. A Cargill spokesman, Mark Klein, said the company is investigating the incident and will work with United States and South Korean officials.

abstract: LAW ON STRANDED PASSENGERS Airlines operating in New York would be required to provide fresh air, toilet-waste removal, drinking water and snacks to passengers on an airplane that has left the gate and remains parked on an airport apron under a new state law signed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer last week. The legislation, originally drafted by a state assemblyman from Queens, Michael N. Gianaris, would take effect Jan. 1, although the airline industry has said it is considering a legal challenge. The Airline Passengers Bill of Rights came in response to instances of passengers being stranded for hours on parked planes, with inadequate ventilation and food and deteriorating hygienic conditions. On Feb. 14, for example, thousands of JetBlue passengers sat on parked planes during a snow and ice storm for as long as 10 hours at Kennedy International Airport.

abstract: Infineon Technologies, the European semiconductor maker, dismissed its chief financial officer, Rüdiger A. Günther, left, after three months on the job because of disagreements between him and the company. Mr. Günther, 49, will leave immediately and Peter Fischl, who was finance chief until retiring in May, will take the post temporarily, according to the company. Mr. Günther declined to comment on the conflict, as did Guenter Gaugler, a spokesman for Infineon.

abstract: Japan’s broadest indicator of the outlook for growth signaled for the first time in eight months that the economy would expand. The leading index climbed to 80 percent in June, the Cabinet Office said, the first time it has been at or over 50 since October. A reading of 50 or more indicates the economy may expand in three to six months. The index is derived from as many as 12 monthly indicators. “The economy will probably accelerate in coming months as a pickup in U.S. exports brings a positive impact on the economy over all,” said Takeshi Minami, chief economist at the Norinchukin Research Institute in Tokyo. “As foreign demand remains robust, we can expect sustainable growth.”.

abstract: Wal-Mart Stores and the Bharti Group of India have agreed to set up wholesale stores and a supply chain in India, eight months after they signed an initial agreement. Their venture will open its first wholesale store by the end of 2008, according to Rajan Mittal, the joint managing director of Bharti Enterprises, who spoke at a news conference in New Delhi. Wal-Mart signed a tentative agreement to start a wholesaling business with the Bharti Group in November. The venture, a 50-50 partnership known as Bharti Wal-Mart Private, is planning to open 10 to 15 wholesale stores over the next seven years to sell to small retailers, hotels and restaurants. The proposed Bharti venture would supply the retail market with goods that come directly from producers like farmers, craftsmen and artisans, Mr. Mittal said.

abstract: The U.S. resumed its trade dispute over Canadian softwood lumber, just 13 months after signing an agreement intended to settle the decades-old issue.
snippet: The U.S. resumed its trade dispute over Canadian softwood lumber, just 13 months after signing an agreement intended to settle the decades-old issue.
lead_paragraph: The United States resumed its trade dispute over Canadian softwood lumber, just 13 months after signing an agreement intended to settle the decades-old issue. Susan C. Schwab, the United States trade representative, said in a statement that she would seek binding arbitration over allegations that Canada is not upholding its commitments under the accord. The United States contends that Canada should have begun reducing exports from British Columbia and Alberta in January and that it gives the lumber industry in Ontario and Quebec unfair assistance. David Emerson, Canada’s international trade minister, said in a statement that the dispute stems from “differing interpretations of the Softwood Lumber Agreement by Canada and the U.S.”

abstract: Australia’s central bank raised its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point to 6.5 percent, the highest rate in almost 11 years.
snippet: Australia’s central bank raised its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point to 6.5 percent, the highest rate in almost 11 years.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s central bank raised its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point to the highest rate in almost 11 years. The bank raised the overnight cash rate to 6.5 percent, the first adjustment since November, to curb inflation running faster than the bank had forecast and to cool the biggest surge in lending since 1989. The increase might undermine Prime Minister John Howard’s campaign this year to win a fifth term. “This does not help the government in the lead-up to the campaign,” said John Edwards, the chief economist at HSBC Bank Australia in Sydney.

headline.main: Central Bank Raises a Key Interest Rate
headline.print_headline: Central Bank Raises a Key Interest Rate

lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of air pollution and noise pollution? Don’t look now, but another depressing form of toxicity is taking the fun out of life: ad pollution. abstract: The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese mobile phone company, posted an eighteenfold increase in first-quarter profit after adding users at a pace twice that of the market leader, NTT DoCoMo.
snippet: The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese mobile phone company, posted an eighteenfold increase in first-quarter profit after adding users at a pace twice that of the market leader, NTT DoCoMo.
lead_paragraph: The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese mobile phone company, posted an eighteenfold increase in first-quarter profit after adding users at a pace twice that of the market leader, NTT DoCoMo. Net income rose to 25.1 billion yen ($211 million), or 22.36 yen a share, in the three months that ended June 30, from 1.42 billion yen, or 0.81 yen a share, a year earlier, Softbank said. Earnings were helped by one-time gains. Operating profit rose 45 percent, to 78.7 billion yen. Softbank cut prices to as little as 980 yen a month, the lowest in Japan, and said it would extend coverage by installing more base stations. Overall sales at Softbank, which controls 17 percent of the mobile market, increased 34 percent, to 663.1 billion yen.

headline.main: Japan: Mobile Phone Company’s Profit Surges
headline.print_headline: Japan: Mobile Phone Company’s Profit Surges

abstract: With Dow Jones & Company set to become part of Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, Gannett is sometimes touted as the next potential takeover target in the newspaper industry. But it is so huge — with a market capitalization of nearly $11 billion — that it is hard to imagine who the acquirer would be. Jon Morton, a newspaper analyst, told The New York Times in June that only a big, non-media buyer — he mentioned General Electric or a buyout firm — could possibly do such a deal, and even that’s unlikely.

abstract: Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, reported a fifth consecutive decline in quarterly profit after a strike led to more fixed-line customer losses.
snippet: Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, reported a fifth consecutive decline in quarterly profit after a strike led to more fixed-line customer losses.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, reported a fifth consecutive decline in quarterly profit after a strike led to more fixed-line customer losses. Second-quarter net income fell to 608 million euros ($831 million) from, 1.02 billion euros a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 2.9 percent, to 15.6 billion euros. Revenue from abroad topped German sales for the first time after Deutsche Telekom lost 516,000 traditional phone lines in its home market while it added mobile phone customers in the United States. To help meet a 2 billion-euro cost-reduction goal this year, Deutsche Telekom moved 50,000 service employees into the new T- Service unit and cut their salaries, starting the biggest strike in more than a decade. The six-week strike ended in June after the Ver.di union agreed to a compromise reduction.

headline.main: Germany: Strike Affects Telecom
headline.print_headline: Germany: Strike Affects Telecom

abstract: The Bank of Korea unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate for a second time in two months to curb lending that may fuel asset-price bubbles.
snippet: The Bank of Korea unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate for a second time in two months to curb lending that may fuel asset-price bubbles.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of Korea unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate for a second time in two months to curb lending that may fuel asset-price bubbles. Governor Lee Seong Tae, left, and his board increased the overnight call rate by a quarter point, to 5 percent, the highest since July 2001, the central bank said. Mr. Lee wants to prevent households from building up excessive debt as they did four years ago, when one in 13 people was unable to pay back money owed and lenders, including LG Card, were driven to the brink of bankruptcy. Lending to households rose at the fastest pace in five months in July.

The jobless rate dropped to 3.6 percent, from a revised 3.7 percent in the first quarter, Statistics New Zealand said. Companies added 14,000 workers. The central bank governor, Alan Bollard, raised the benchmark interest rate to a record 8.25 percent last month, saying four increases this year might contain inflation.

abstract: The Citic Securities Company, the Asian brokerage firm, said first-half profit rose more than fivefold as a surging Chinese stock market fueled share trading and underwriting fees. Net income rose to 4.2 billion yuan ($554 million), from last year’s 775.8 million yuan, Citic said. Brokerage commissions at Citic, which is based in Beijing, rose sixfold, to 6.6 billion yuan, in the first half. Citic Securities made 473 million yuan, or 4.4 percent of its revenue, from arranging share sales in the first half. Its investment banking division is the leading underwriter this year, with 20.1 percent of the market. Citic and its units have 165 branches and more than 5,000 employees.

abstract: The inflation rate in Britain unexpectedly fell last month below the Bank of England’s 2 percent target for the first time since March 2006, weakening the case for another interest rate increase. Consumer prices rose 1.9 percent in July from a year earlier, down from 2.4 percent in June, the Office for National Statistics said. Economists had expected inflation, which accelerated to a decade high of 3.1 percent in March, to slow to 2.3 percent last month. So-called core inflation, which excludes energy, food, tobacco and alcohol, slowed to 1.7 percent in July, down from a decade high of 2 percent in June.

abstract: David Leonhardt explores how an investing system of the past could aid analysis of today’s stock market.
snippet: David Leonhardt explores how an investing system of the past could aid analysis of today’s stock market.
lead_paragraph: More than 70 years ago, two Columbia professors named Benjamin Graham and David L. Dodd came up with a simple investing idea that remains more influential than perhaps any other. In the wake of the stock market crash in 1929, they urged investors to focus on hard facts — like a company’s past earnings and the value of its assets — rather than trying to guess what the future would bring. A company with strong profits and a relatively low stock price was probably undervalued, they said.

headline.main: Remembering a Classic Investing Theory
headline.print_headline: 1934 Classic Says Be Wary Right Now

abstract: China’s retail sales grew at the fastest rate in more than three years, helped by a stock market rally and higher wages and prices. Spending climbed 16.4 percent, to 699.8 billion yuan ($92 billion) in July from a year earlier, after gaining 16 percent in June, the National Bureau of Statistics said. The figures are not adjusted for inflation. The biggest increase in consumer prices in a decade contributed to the acceleration. Stock market gains and a 14 percent jump in urban incomes underpinned demand. “Inflation played an important role in gains for food sales,” said Paul Tang, chief economist at Bank of East Asia in Hong Kong. “But in other categories, there’s genuine continued gains, and overall growth is steady.”.

Stock market gains and a 14 percent jump in urban incomes underpinned demand. “Inflation played an important role in gains for food sales,” said Paul Tang, chief economist at Bank of East Asia in Hong Kong. “But in other categories, there’s genuine continued gains, and overall growth is steady.”

abstract: Indonesia’s economy grew the fastest in more than two years in the second quarter as exports rose and lower interest rates fueled spending and investment.
snippet: Indonesia’s economy grew the fastest in more than two years in the second quarter as exports rose and lower interest rates fueled spending and investment.
lead_paragraph: Indonesia’s economy grew the fastest in more than two years in the second quarter as exports rose and lower interest rates fueled spending and investment. The economy expanded 6.3 percent in the three months ended June 30 after gaining 6 percent in the previous quarter, the Central Statistics Bureau said. Private consumption increased 4.7 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, according to the report. Manufacturing expanded 5.5 percent, construction rose 7.8 percent and agriculture gained 2.4 percent. Government spending was up 3.8 percent. Exports rose 9.8 percent on rising overseas sales of commodities, including palm oil and coal, the report said, while imports increased 7.2 percent.

headline.main: Indonesia: High Economic Growth
headline.print_headline: Indonesia: High Economic Growth

lead_paragraph: When I was a boy I used to sit with my dad in front of the TV and watch football games. He would explain the rules and tell me about the teams and the important players while I tuned him out, distracted by what looked to me like a chaotic free-for-all. I never had the slightest idea what was going on in the game and usually wasn’t even sure where the ball was.

abstract: China’s industrial production rose 18 percent in July, slowing for the first time in three months after reductions in export incentives.
snippet: China’s industrial production rose 18 percent in July, slowing for the first time in three months after reductions in export incentives.
lead_paragraph: China’s industrial production rose 18 percent in July, slowing for the first time in three months after reductions in export incentives. Output grew less than June’s 19.4 percent, the statistics bureau said. The slowdown is not likely to ease government concern that the economy may be overheating. “This is still a pretty robust number, highlighting the momentum of the Chinese economy supported by exports and retail demand,” said David Cohen, an economist at Action Economics in Singapore. It’s premature to speculate that the economy is slowing, Mr. Cohen said. Exports jumped 34.2 percent in July from a year earlier, the fastest pace in five months. Retail sales gained 16.4 percent, the biggest increase since May 2004 after adjusting for Lunar New Year distortions.

headline.main: China: Production Pace Slows
headline.print_headline: China: Production Pace Slows

abstract: The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos, the oil company, sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of Yukos.
snippet: The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos, the oil company, sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of Yukos.
lead_paragraph: The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos, the oil company, sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of Yukos. As in previous sales, the property went to a little-known company for far less than its nominal value The buyer was a Russian real estate firm, Monte-Valle, which is owned by an American businessman, Stephen Lynch, who has worked in Russia for more than 10 years. Most of the oil fields, machinery and other Yukos assets inside Russia have already been sold. Outside of Russia, what remains of Yukos, once the country’s largest private company, is consolidated in a Netherlands-registered foundation that Yukos shareholders say controls roughly 2 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in cash and equities; the foundation is under the supervision of a Dutch bankruptcy court. The sale sets the stage for a complex and high-stakes legal struggle in the Netherlands between Mr. Lynch and former Yukos shareholders, who argue that the Russian bankruptcy process is illegitimate.

headline.main: Russia: Sale of Some Yukos Assets
headline.print_headline: Russia: Sale of Some Yukos Assets

snippet: The Internet phone service Skype suffers an outage and may stay down for a whole day.
lead_paragraph: The massively popular Internet phone service Skype has been down all morning. Its Web site says that engineers have discovered a software problem which will be fixed in 12 to 24 hours. That is a disastrously long time for a service that eBay, owner of Skype, has been pitching as a core business communication tool to companies and stay-at-home professionals. In fact last year, eBay itself revealed it would begin weaning itself off landlines and instead use Skype as its primary phone service. Not surprisingly, I’ve been unable to raise anyone at eBay all morning.

headline.main: Skype’s Bad Day

abstract: Qantas Airways, Australia’s biggest airline, said second-half profit almost tripled and announced plans to buy back 10 percent of its stock.
snippet: Qantas Airways, Australia’s biggest airline, said second-half profit almost tripled and announced plans to buy back 10 percent of its stock.
lead_paragraph: Qantas Airways, Australia’s biggest airline, said second-half profit almost tripled and announced plans to buy back 10 percent of its stock. Net income in the six months ended June 30 rose to 361.1 million Australian dollars ($299 million) from 127.4 million Australian dollars a year earlier, the company said. Qantas, based in Sydney, forecast pretax profit would rise 30 percent this fiscal year. The chief executive, Geoffrey J. Dixon, said the airline might sell or spin off its freight, holiday and air miles units, adopting strategies proposed by the Macquarie Bank-led buyout group that made a bid of 11.1 billion Australian dollars in May. The chairwoman, Margaret Jackson, above, who will leave in November after being criticized for her support of the buyout, said the company would spend about a billion Australian dollars buying back 10 percent of its stock.

headline.main: Australia: Qantas Reports a Jump in Profit

abstract: Russian industrial production growth slowed in July after expanding at the fastest annual rate in two and a half years in June, the Federal Statistics Service said.
snippet: Russian industrial production growth slowed in July after expanding at the fastest annual rate in two and a half years in June, the Federal Statistics Service said.
lead_paragraph: Russian industrial production growth slowed in July after expanding at the fastest annual rate in two and a half years in June, the Federal Statistics Service said. Output grew at an annual rate of 7.8 percent in July, down from 10.9 percent in June, the Statistics Service said. For the month, output fell 2.7 percent after expanding by 4.5 percent in June. Manufacturing output expanded at an annual rate of 12.5 percent in July, compared with 15.6 percent in June, the statistics office said. Electricity, gas and water output expansion accelerated to an annual 3.3 percent from 2.9 percent in June. Mining and quarrying grew 1.2 percent in July, slower than the 2 percent pace of the previous month.

headline.main: Russia: Industrial Output Slows
headline.print_headline: Russia: Industrial Output Slows

abstract: Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers.
snippet: Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers.
lead_paragraph: Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers. Sales climbed 0.7 percent after gaining 0.4 percent in June, which was twice as much as previously reported, the Office for National Statistics said. Tesco, Britain’s biggest retailer, and Asda, owned by Wal-Mart Stores, cut prices on thousands of products to attract customers during the wettest summer on record. The gain in retail sales was led by electronics and furniture, the statistics office said. Household goods stores reported a 13.4 percent annual increase in sales, the biggest since October 2001. Retail sales rose 4.4 percent from a year earlier. Analysts said the strong figures would encourage the central bank to raise interest rates.

headline.main: Britain: Retail Sales Post Gain
headline.print_headline: Britain: Retail Sales Post Gain

abstract: In what may be the most lukewarm upgrade of the week, an analyst at Banc of America Securities on Friday raised his rating on Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the United States, from “sell” to “neutral.” The less-than-ringing endorsement came a few days after an analyst at Merrill Lynch slashed his Countrywide rating from “buy” to “sell” and flagged the possibility that the mortgage giant could end up in bankruptcy.

abstract: FIRST COMMERCIAL A380 FLIGHT Singapore Airlines will begin auctioning seats on eBay next Monday for the first commercial flight of the A380 superjumbo jet, scheduled for Oct. 25 from Singapore to Sydney. Proceeds will go to charity. Singapore will be the first airline to take delivery of the long-delayed Airbus double-decker aircraft, which is certified to hold 853 passengers in a single-class configuration. Singapore said it would configure its A380s with 471 seats in three classes: economy, business and what the airline calls “a class beyond first.” No United States carriers have ordered the planes, but international airlines that are buying A380s have all said they intend to fly them with no more than about 550 passengers in economy and premium cabins. Singapore, which has ordered 19 A380s, has not yet unveiled its new first-class cabins for the jets, but is expected to do so soon. A380s have previously flown passengers on noncommercial demonstration flights.

lead_paragraph: TIP OF THE WEEK: Don’t rely on a confusing (or broken) hotel alarm clock when traveling. Most cellphones include an alarm-clock function. Check your phone’s Tools or Applications menu. And if your phone can receive text messages and you use Google’s or Yahoo’s calendar, you can set the software to send appointment reminders to your phone so you know where you have to be once you get up.

lead_paragraph: Leona Helmsley may be dead but her oft-quoted sentiment that “only the little people pay taxes” lives on at CBS. In an amendment to his contract as C.E.O. of CBS, Leslie Moonves obtained the company’s promise to pay any state or local taxes he might incur in New York. The amendment states that Mr. Moonves, who lives in Southern California, cannot claim that having to work now and then in Manhattan is a “good reason” for quitting his job. But, it says, if New York authorities try to tax him for earning income in their territory, CBS will pick up the bill.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 — The idea of micropayments — charging Web users tiny amounts of money for single pieces of online content — was essentially put to sleep toward the end of the dot-com boom. In December 2000, Clay Shirky, an adjunct professor in New York University’s interactive telecommunications program, wrote a manifesto that people still cite whenever someone suggests resurrecting the idea. Micropayments will never work, he wrote, mainly because “users hate them.”

lead_paragraph: George Hotz, a New Jersey teenager, got most of the attention last week for hacking the iPhone, but at least one other group claims to have come up with a way of liberating Apple’s popular gadget from AT&T’s wireless network. A group calling itself iPhoneSimFree, which first demonstrated its technique to Engadget’s editor, Ryan Block, said it could unlock the iPhone without any changes to the iPhone hardware itself. If it works, the solution could potentially be more broadly accessible to people who want to use their iPhones on GSM networks other than AT&T’s.

abstract: Bombardier, the commercial aircraft maker, posted a quarterly loss after writing off its investment in the Metronet Rail subway unit in Britain.
snippet: Bombardier, the commercial aircraft maker, posted a quarterly loss after writing off its investment in the Metronet Rail subway unit in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Bombardier, the commercial aircraft maker, posted a quarterly loss after writing off its investment in the Metronet Rail subway unit in Britain. The results, however, topped analysts’ estimates. The net loss was $71 million, or 5 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $58 million, or 3 cents, a year earlier, Bombardier said. Sales in the second quarter, which ended July 31, rose 15 percent, to $4.04 billion. Metronet, the London Underground contractor in which Bombardier and four European companies were joint-venture partners, collapsed last month at a cost to Bombardier of $162 million in write-offs. Excluding the Metronet charge, profit at Bombardier, which is based in Montreal, rose 60 percent, to $91 million.

headline.main: Canada: Bombardier Posts Loss on Write-Off
headline.print_headline: Canada: Bombardier Posts Loss On Write-Off

abstract: Cnooc, a Chinese offshore oil producer, said first-half profit declined 11 percent, less than analysts had expected, as the company reined in operating costs.
snippet: Cnooc, a Chinese offshore oil producer, said first-half profit declined 11 percent, less than analysts had expected, as the company reined in operating costs.
lead_paragraph: Cnooc, a Chinese offshore oil producer, said first-half profit declined 11 percent, less than analysts had expected, as the company reined in operating costs. Net income slid to 14.6 billion yuan ($1.9 billion) from 16.3 billion yuan a year earlier, the Beijing-based company said, reflecting lower average oil prices. Oil and gas production rose to the equivalent of about 467,000 barrels of oil a day, Cnooc said. Oil and gas sales fell 6.4 percent, to 33.2 billion yuan. The average price Cnooc received for its oil fell 5.8 percent, to $58.80 a barrel. Gas prices gained 1.3 percent.

headline.main: China: Earnings Decline 11% at Oil Producer
headline.print_headline: China: Earnings Decline 11% at Oil Producer

abstract: After 13 years of reviewing drafts, the National People’s Congress approved a law that bans price-fixing, collusion, excessive market concentration and other monopolistic practices by private and state-owned businesses alike.
snippet: After 13 years of reviewing drafts, the National People’s Congress approved a law that bans price-fixing, collusion, excessive market concentration and other monopolistic practices by private and state-owned businesses alike.
lead_paragraph: After 13 years of reviewing drafts, the National People’s Congress approved a law that bans price-fixing, collusion, excessive market concentration and other monopolistic practices by private and state-owned businesses alike. The law marks another step toward a market economy and away from a centrally planned economy in which a series of giant state-owned enterprises held vast and unchallenged monopolies. The law’s most controversial provision, added this summer, calls for the government to conduct more formal reviews of foreign purchases of Chinese companies based on their potential to harm national security, including economic security. The law will take effect on Aug. 1, 2008.

headline.main: China: Antimonopoly Law Approved
headline.print_headline: China: Antimonopoly Law Approved

abstract: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal.
snippet: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal.
lead_paragraph: President Nicolas Sarkozy said he favored a merger of Gaz de France and the energy operations of Suez, implying Suez would have to shed its waste and water units to complete the long-pending deal. “I’ve proposed that Suez merge its energy business with Gaz de France to create a large gas and electricity group,” Mr. Sarkozy, left, said in a speech to a Paris business group. “This requires that Suez make a strategic choice to specialize in energy.” Suez’s chief executive, Gerard Mestrallet, has resisted considering a sale of the waste and water units, which account for about a third of operations. He declined to say whether he would be willing to hive them off for the deal to go through. The original plan to combine Suez and Gaz de France is now valued at about 56 billion euros ($76 billion). It has been mired in political and valuation concerns since it was first put forward in February 2006 to ward off a possible bid for Suez from Enel of Italy and to create Europe’s second-biggest utility.

headline.main: France: Sarkozy Favors a Utility Merger
headline.print_headline: France: Sarkozy Favors a Utility Merger

abstract: A federal court judge dealt a blow to Johnson & Johnson in its $5.5 billion lawsuit over the sale of Guidant to Boston Scientific, dismissing some claims and only allowing part of the case to proceed. The ruling, which was made public on Thursday, throws out the case against Abbott Laboratories but allows J&J to go ahead with its claim against Guidant for breach of contract.
lead_paragraph: A federal court judge dealt a blow to Johnson & Johnson in its $5.5 billion lawsuit over the sale of Guidant to Boston Scientific, dismissing some claims and only allowing part of the case to proceed. abstract: Deutsche Bank has shut down its proprietary credit trading desk in London and up to seven employees have left the bank – including department head Gerry Jackson – as the credit crunch claimed yet more scalps Thursday. The remaining members of the team, believed to be about 15 strong, have been given other jobs in the bank, according to The Telegraph.
